instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1534: What is A1534? A1534 is a model number for a 12 inch size Macbook  from years 2015, 2016 with EMC 2746, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00045, 820-00244..
definitions.820-00244: What is 820-00244? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP3V3R3V0_AON: What is PP3V3R3V0_AON? PP3V3R3V0_AON is the first power rail you need to get a USB-C charger to go from 5v to 20v on an A1534 Macbook with an 820-00045 board..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> stuck at 5.19V 1.42amp
threads.message:
before this is fully working board with keyboard issue only, 
i just accidentally removed th <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip by mistake. but when i 
put back the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip got this 5.19V 1.42amp even i changed new <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>. 

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0v 0.427  (diode to ground)
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>|<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 5.2V

<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> 0V 0.518  (diode to ground)
<SIGNAL>PP1V8D_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8A_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> 1.77V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> 3.27V

what to do next???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> stuck at 5.19V 1.42amp
threads.message:
1.4A is very high current for 5V on USB port and no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
I suppose overcurrent on <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>, or <SIGNAL>3V0_AON</SIGNAL> power rail; check exact voltage and diode mode to ground there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> stuck at 5.19V 1.42amp
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> stuck at 5.19V 1.42amp
threads.message:
Something should heat on the board.
An IR thermal cam helps to find it; possibly <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> stuck at 5.19V 1.42amp
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> was replaced
theres no heat on the board
using ir camera theres no heat greater than 26 degree celcius

what can be posibly damage after removing <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> stuck at 5.19V 1.42amp
threads.message: What is the actual current consumption on USB-C port?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> stuck at 5.19V 1.42amp
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> stuck at 5.19V 1.42amp
threads.message:
Is that without battery?

Test the board w/o battery connected.
Cannot have such big consumption in off state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> stuck at 5.19V 1.42amp
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> stuck at 5.19V 1.42amp
threads.message:
Nothing will overheat, but your board takes around 7W in off state.
That's the reason I said to use IR cam; cannot detect small heat other way.

Which component appears with 26 degrees?
Being the "hotest" one in this case...
